statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Shawn Marion scored 23 points, and Stephon Marbury had 20 and 11 assists in just three quarters as the Phoenix Suns won their season-high fifth straight game Monday night with a 110-93 victory over Golden Stat
article.headline: Suns win fifth straight; Warriors drop fourth in a row
article.linkText: Marion keeps Sun rising in easy victory over Warriors
article.story:
PHOENIX (AP) -- The Phoenix Suns understandably got a little lax at the end of their game against the Golden State Warriors.
Marion

By then, Shawn Marion, Stephon Marbury and Penny Hardaway were on the bench watching reserves finish off the Suns' 21st win in 25 games against the Warriors. Marion scored 23 points, and Stephon Marbury had 20 and 11 assists in just three quarters as Phoenix won its season-high fifth straight game Monday night with a 110-93 victory over Golden State. "It's always good when you can sit down in the fourth quarter when you're winning," Marbury said. "It's fun to win, man." Rodney Rogers had 15 points and Hardaway added 14 for Phoenix. Marion, who had 19 points at halftime, also had nine rebounds and six assists. "They were quicker than us tonight," Warriors coach Dave Cowens said. "They got into the paint. We just couldn't keep a guy in front of us." Larry Hughes scored 19 points for the Warriors, who lost their fourth in a row. "This is tough," Hughes said. "We've just got to sustain it and play good defense. A lot of teams' runs are like eight or 10 (points), but teams are running up 20-25 on us and getting big leads." Antawn Jamison had 16 and 11 rebounds, and Danny Fortson had 12 points and 10 rebounds. The Suns had a 15-point lead at halftime and put the game away in the third quarter, when they outscored Golden State 31-24. The separation began late in what had been a close first quarter. Marbury had four points and had an assist in the final 1:55 as the Suns finished the quarter with a 6-0 spurt. It grew into a 20-5 run in the first four minutes of the second as Marion's third straight basket sent Phoenix to a 38-22 lead. The Suns maintained a double-digit lead from then on. The Warriors made it 60-50 on a three-point play by Jamison 3:34 into the third quarter, but Hardaway started a 21-4 run with a 3-pointer 10 seconds later to start a 21-4 surge that put Phoenix ahead 81-54 with 3:28 left in the quarter. Marion and coach Scott Skiles said defense was the key to the Phoenix's scoring. "Shawn was active once again on defense," Skiles said. "I thought he did a great job on Jamison, and that always gets him going. That always gets him -- somehow, some way -- some easy hoops." Everyone on the team is making an effort to stop the other team, Marion said. "The shots are going to be there, so it's just a matter of us going out there and stopping people," he said. Game notes
The Warriors topped their NBA-leading average by getting 21 offensive rebounds, but trailed the Suns 21-18 on second-chance points. ... The Suns have won four straight at home. ... Phoenix is 8-2 since Nov. 16, when it acquired Bo Outlaw and activated Dan Majerle from injured reserve.
